subject: Art & Design
title: The Three-Act Structure in Screenwriting
description: A quick, practical guide to The Three-Act Structure in Screenwriting.

hook.text: Boy meets girl (Act 1). Boy loses girl (Act 2). Boy wins girl back (Act 3). Every romcom. Every time.

buildup.text: The three-act structure divides a story into setup, confrontation, and resolution. It's cinema's backbone.

discovery.text: Act 1 hooks you (first 25%). Act 2 tests the hero with escalating obstacles (next 50%). Act 3 resolves it (final 25%).

twist.text: Some filmmakers reject it entirely. Pulp Fiction scrambles chronology. Memento runs backwards.

climax.text: The structure works because it mirrors how humans process stories: question, struggle, answer.

punchline.text: Three acts aren't a formula. They're how brains expect stories to unfold.

quiz.question: What are the three acts in traditional screenwriting structure?
